node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
The world’s animals and wildlife are going extinct at a greater rate than at any time in human history. Can technology help turn the tide?

Cover image credit: Yashpal Rathore/Nature Picture Library

node.title: Mass extinction: what can stop it?

node.text: For most of 2020 the theory that covid-19 leaked from a Chinese lab was dismissed as unlikely. In the past few months it has gained currency. Our experts explain why. Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: Did covid-19 leak from a Chinese lab?

node.text: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies set out to upend the financial order and replace conventional money. Bitcoin has certainly disrupted the global financial system, but can it ever live up to the hype? Cover credit: Jakub Porzycki/Getty Images

node.title: Crypto: will the bitcoin dream succeed?

Jair Bolsonaro’s actions do not just threaten Brazilian democracy—they have also endangered one of the world’s most important natural resources.

node.text: Myanmar is on the brink of collapse. Its armed forces are continuing a brutal crackdown—arresting, torturing and killing protesters—as Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar’s de-facto leader, is detained. Our experts answer your questions. Cover image: STR/ Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021.

node.text:
Civil partnerships gave gay couples in Britain the same rights as marriage gave straight couples. Soon after they were introduced, in 2004, straight people wanted to get them too. ⁠
⁠
After a long campaign to change the law, straight couples in Britain are now able to get civil partnerships.⁠
⁠
They appeal to couples who want a modern, equal partnership, clean of assumptions about what a marriage should be. ⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to read why @1843mag thinks we should raise a toast to this modern form of marriage.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Mari Fouz

node.text:
Today marks the 70th anniversary of the United Nations’ refugee convention, a landmark treaty that established the obligations that countries have to people fleeing persecution. ⁠
⁠
It has become perhaps the least popular treaty in the rich world. ⁠
⁠
The world is creating more and more refugees, even as fewer and fewer governments have the appetite to protect them. ⁠
⁠
“Countries face a difficult obligation to winnow out who’s a genuine refugee,” our correspondent tells “The Intelligence”. ⁠
⁠
Part of the challenge they face is that a lot of people on the move are economic migrants. Many who arrive in Europe or at the southern borders of the United States are genuinely fleeing persecution, and some are looking for a better life.⁠
⁠
The world has changed a lot since the treaty was agreed in 1951. Is it still fit for purpose? Our correspondent says not. To find out why, tap the link in our bio to listen to the podcast.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Business Facebook is looking to a future beyond social media f'.

node.text:
⁠Facebook will present its second-quarter results later today. The company looks poised to become a long-term member of the exclusive club of companies with a market value above $1trn, which it joined earlier this year.⁠
⁠
At its core Facebook is a giant advertising machine. Adverts generate 98% of its revenue.⁠
⁠
But a new generation of apps threatens the social network's business model. If consumers tire of its products and move elsewhere, advertisers might follow.⁠
⁠
Can new ventures take Facebook further? Click on the link in our bio to read about Mark Zuckerberg's vision for the social network. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Americans say their individual well-being improved in 2020 Well-being score, 0=highest 56 58 60 62 64 66 54 Overall community well- being Overall social determinants Overall individual well-being Determined by: Physical well-being Social Community Purpose Financial 2019 2020 Sources: Sharecare; Blavatnik School of Government, University of Oxford The Economist'.

node.text:
A new study finds that individual well-being has improved for many Americans over the past year despite the pandemic and lockdowns. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Social well-being is highest in the richest states, in the north-east and west. But there is no obvious reason why some states have improved more than others. The five states enjoying the greatest improvement—Maryland, Delaware, South Dakota, Alabama, and Minnesota—do not appear to have much in common.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The pandemic may have made Americans seek more support from friends, prompting an improvement in social well-being. Still more analysis of data, disaggregated by demographic differences, is needed to solve the mystery of why the average American’s well-being improved during a pandemic.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The survey’s findings may not be easily generalisable to other countries though. Click on the link in our bio to find out why.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021. Photo by The Economist on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'By Invitation Trans Olympians are dividing opinion. Why? Two athletes explore both perspectives'.

node.text:
For the first time, openly transgender women are competing in female events at the Olympics. ⁠
⁠
Writing a guest commentary for The Economist, teenage track athlete Chelsea Mitchell argues that the policy "undermines the integrity of the competition”.⁠
⁠
"It establishes unfairness at the very heart of the most important athletic competition in the world," she writes.⁠
⁠
But in a separate article for us, in opposition of this view, Veronica Ivy, the first openly transgender world track-cycling champion, argues the policy is fair and cause for celebration.⁠
⁠
"From the standpoint of human rights, sport is welcoming of all people. And transgender women are women in the ways that matter," she writes.⁠
⁠
To read both athletes' perspectives, click on the link in our bio.

node.text:
Our Big Mac Index was invented in 1986 as a digestible guide to whether currencies are at their “correct” level. ⁠
⁠
For those of you who like happy meals in unhappy places, the cheapest burger we could find is in Lebanon.⁠
⁠
Although the price of a Big Mac has increased spectacularly to 37,000 Lebanese pounds, the currency has collapsed even more dramatically on the black market, where 22,000 pounds buy a dollar. ⁠
⁠
The result is a Big Mac that costs the equivalent of only $1.68, a sad reflection of the country’s economic disaster.⁠
⁠
Elsewhere though, Big Mac prices are supersizing. Tap the link in our bio to read more about burgernomics.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Asia Rodrigo Duterte wants to avoid a lame-duck end to his presidency PANGULO NG SAGISAG'.

node.text:
Rodrigo Duterte seems determined not to appear like a man about to retire.⁠
⁠
“This is by no means my swansong,” the president of the Philippines said in his final speech on the state of the nation, presenting legislators with a list of laws to pass in the 11 months that remain of his six-year term. ⁠
⁠
Polls suggest the controversial leader is the most popular since the overthrow in 1986 of Ferdinand Marcos.⁠
⁠
But if legislators come to believe that he will retire once his successor is elected next year, his authority may quickly evaporate. ⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to read why it is safe to assume that Mr Duterte will not waddle off quietly. ⁠
⁠
Credit: Jam Sta Rosa/POOL/AFP via Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The Americas Mexico's middle class is being battered by the pandemic, and its president O g O 0 Q Q g'.

node.text:
In recent decades Mexico, like many emerging markets, has witnessed the growth of its middle class.⁠
⁠
The growth of a large swathe of people who are neither rich nor poor in the country owes much to NAFTA, a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada.⁠
⁠
If public services improved, middle-class Mexicans could spend their money on other things—and more people could climb the ladder, too. ⁠
⁠
But being middle class in Mexico is a far more precarious status than in richer places. An economic shock—a family illness or a recession—can send people tumbling back into poverty. Click the link in our bio to find out why.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @lo_cole

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BURSTING THE BUBBLE: HOW GUM LOST ITS COOL'.

node.text:
There was a time when chewing gum was a symbol of rebellion, bravado and sex appeal. Those days are now gone.⁠
⁠
Gum has had a bad pandemic: with mouths covered by masks, dates delayed and clubbing cancelled, annual sales fell by 14% worldwide in 2020. ⁠
⁠
Yet the product had been in decline even before covid struck, says 1843 magazine. ⁠
⁠
So why has gum come unstuck? To find out why Gen Z doesn't see the appeal, tap on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: Albane Simon/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Without action, a 3°℃ temperature rise is a likely outcome for the world Warming above pre-industrial levels in 2100, °C 1.5 target 2.0 Optimistic scenario including net-zero goals 2.4 formal pre-Cop 26 pledges and targets met 1.2 Warming by 2020 2.9 Under policies in place 1 68% confidence 2 3 Source: Climate Action Tracker The Economist'.

node.text:
The Paris agreement says that global warming should be limited to "well below 2°C", but how likely is this? ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
As the first chart shows, if existing government targets are met and promises kept there is a 68% chance that global average temperatures will rise by between 1.9°C and 3.0°C above pre-industrial levels.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
The consequences are dire. Those modelling climate impacts have long argued that they do not increase linearly. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Swipe left to look at two maps.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Just as today’s world is not uniformly 1.2°C warmer than the pre-industrial, a 3°C world is not uniformly 1.8°C warmer than today. Some regions, chiefly the oceans and parts of South America, will warm less; others will get much hotter.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
A 3°C world will bring more frequent and more extreme heatwaves to regions that have little or no experience of such things. Neither coral reefs nor the Amazon rainforest are likely to survive. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To read about the other alarming ways in which this level of warming will transform Earth, click on the link in our bio.

Photo by The Economist on July 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Business How should managers run teams remotely? A new book offers leadership tips'.

node.text:
The pandemic has posed a challenge to managers trying to build rapport and maintain productivity in their teams. ⁠
⁠
A new book, “Leading at a Distance”, attempts to provide some practical tips for such managers.⁠
⁠
The authors are not in the gloomy camp that believes remote working is a disaster. They point out that the ability to hire people who can work anywhere means that businesses will find it easier to develop more diverse workforces. ⁠
⁠
The book also offers some useful advice. For starters, keep virtual teams small. And beware the dangers of poorly-run virtual meetings.⁠
⁠
What office life doesn’t need is gimmicks. Remote-working colleagues do not need to be treated like game-show contestants⁠
⁠
Much as our our Bartleby columnist would love to hear about one colleague's egg whisk, or another's salad spinner, he hopes one particular team-building idea does not catch on at The Economist.⁠
⁠
To read about other tips on hybrid or remote-working from the book, tap the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @paulyblow

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on July 27, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and crowd.

node.text:
⁠
The future of the Arab world’s only full democracy is uncertain after what’s been described as a presidential “coup”.⁠
⁠
Kais Saied enacted Article 80 of the constitution, under which he suspended parliament for 30 days and dismissed the prime minister, Hichem Mechichi. ⁠
⁠
His decision came a day after protests swept the country. Tens of thousands of Tunisians, braving the sweltering heat and defying a covid-19 lockdown, called for the downfall of the government.⁠
⁠
Some have welcomed Mr Saied’s decision as a necessary intervention, however.⁠
⁠
Tunisia is the one true democracy to emerge from the Arab spring protests of 2010-11 that toppled dictators in a handful of countries. But click the link in our bio to read how it has struggled in the decade since.⁠
⁠
Credit: Photo by STR/EPA-EFE/Shutterstock
